item.title: Ghost of Yotei Detail Seemingly Confirms Which Tsushima Ending Is Canon
item.description:
Some Ghost of Yotei players believe a specific detail in the game confirms which of the two endings from the first entry in the franchise is considered canon. The theory continues a years-long pattern of Sucker Punch sending mixed signals regarding the canonicity of Ghost of Tsushima 's endings.

Ending spoilers for Ghost of Tsushima and minor spoilers for Ghost of Yotei ahead.

Sucker Punch was upfront about Ghost of Yotei taking place over 300 years after Ghost of Tsushima from the moment it revealed its latest game in September 2024. This timeline confirmed that Jin Sakai, the protagonist of the original title, would not be alive during the sequel’s events. However, the developer did not reveal whether the second game would mention him beyond superficial, Easter egg-like references. As it turns out, it would.

Ghost of Yotei Possibly References Ghost of Tsushima's 'Spare' Ending

Ghost of Yotei contains Jin's final resting place. Without spoiling anything else, it can be said that the location is difficult to miss. Some players exploring the grave area have observed that it is filled with red leaves from Japanese maple trees (Acer palmatum), a visual motif prominently featured in Ghost of Tsushima ’s ending where Jin spares Lord Shimura. This has led some to interpret the detail as evidence that the "spare" ending is canon. However, others argue that the Japanese maple is simply a symbol associated with the Sakai family and appears in both endings, even if not with equal emphasis.

Sucker Punch Keeps Sending Mixed Signals About Ghost of Tsushima Canon Ending

Shortly after the first game's July 2020 release, director Nate Fox said that sparing Lord Shimura in Ghost of Tsushima was the game's "true ending" during a Kinda Funny Gamescast interview. That comment would have settled the canonicity debate for good had the developer not later appeared to reverse course, sending mixed signals regarding which ending is the true one. Most recently, Fox asserted that "both endings are valid" in a MinnMax interview conducted shortly before the launch of Ghost of Yotei , declining to confirm either as canon.

GoT Director Saying Sparing Lord Shimura Is the 'True Ending' (July 2020)

GoT Director Saying 'Both Endings Are Valid' (September 2025)

Whether the red leaves genuinely confirm that Lord Shimura survived the events of the first game or not, Fox’s most recent comments suggest it ultimately doesn’t matter, at least not in the context of the sequel. The series is envisioned as more of an anthology, so fans may never receive a definitive answer on canonicity from Sucker Punch, or at least not one that is not prone to change. The choice to set the sequel three centuries later means Ghost of Yotei can be played even without experiencing Ghost of Tsushima , thus being maximally accessible.

44
8.9 /10
9 /10

Ghost of Tsushima

Follow
Followed
Action
Adventure
Systems

Top Critic Avg: 84 /100 Critics Rec: 88%

item.title: Games That Are Like Baldur's Gate 3 But Easier
item.description:
Baldur’s Gate 3 gave players a huge world full of choices, party drama, and fun turn-based battles to explore. It’s one of the best RPGs ever made, but it can also be tough to learn and slow to play. Managing every spell, checking every dice roll, and keeping track of dozens of systems can wear people out, especially those who just want to enjoy the story or explore without reading endless guides.

That’s why some players look for games that feel like Baldur’s Gate 3 but are easier to handle. These games still let players lead a group of heroes, make story-altering decisions, and explore detailed fantasy worlds, but they don’t demand as much time or planning to enjoy. They give the same sense of freedom and character bonding, but with simpler combat and clearer rules.

Divinity: Original Sin 2

A Deep, Choice-Filled RPG That Feels Lighter And Easier To Master

Divinity: Original Sin 2
8.6 /10
Released
September 14, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Language, Sexual Themes, Violence
Developer(s)
Larian Studios
OpenCritic Rating
Mighty
Powered by

Divinity: Original Sin 2 plays a lot like Baldur’s Gate 3 because both were made by Larian Studios and follow a similar formula: a big world, turn-based tactical battles, strong character stories, and player choices that actually matter. The party building, elemental combos, skill interactions, and even the way dialogue changes based on race or background all feel familiar to anyone who has played Baldur's Gate 3 . Players move through a fantasy world where every barrel, crate, and puddle can change the outcome of a fight.

It offers the same kind of strategic depth that BG3 players love, only with simpler rules and more predictability. Divinity: Original Sin 2 still challenges players to think carefully, but it’s more generous about letting them experiment and learn without feeling punished. It gives the same sense of freedom and creativity, just with a smoother learning curve and fewer complicated systems to memorize.

Dragon Age: Origins

A Story-Driven Adventure With Simple Controls

Dragon Age: Origins
9 /10
17
9.1 /10
Released
November 3, 2009

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood, Intense Violence, Language, Partial Nudity, Sexual Content
Developer(s)
BioWare
Powered by

Like Baldur's Gate 3 , every companion in Dragon Age: Origins has unique opinions and personal quests that respond to the player's actions. This makes the game's companions some of the best-written characters in any RPG . The world is filled with political tension and magical lore, giving it the same weighty tone that RPG fans enjoy.

However, Dragon Age: Origins is far simpler to play. Its combat uses real-time action with a pause function, so players can stop the fight at any time, issue commands, and then continue. This removes the stress of calculating every move like in BG3 ’s turn-based system. Players can even automate how party members react in battle using the Tactics menu, which means less micromanaging. The rules are also easier to follow as there’s no need to track dice rolls, modifiers, or obscure D&D mechanics.

Solasta: Crown Of The Magister

A True D&D Experience With Straightforward Rules And Simple Turn-Based Battles

Solasta: Crown of the Magister
9.0 /10
Released
May 27, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
Teen // Violence, Blood, Suggestive Themes, Use of Alcohol, Language
Developer(s)
Tactical Adventures
Powered by

Solasta: Crown of the Magister plays like a smaller, more accessible version of Baldur’s Gate 3 . It offers turn-based combat that relies on positioning, high ground, and lighting, just like Baldur's Gate 3 . The big difference is that Solasta strips away the overwhelming extras.

The world in Solasta is simpler, the story more focused, and the systems easier to understand. The user interface displays every roll and modifier on-screen, helping new players understand why something succeeded or failed. Spells and abilities unlock gradually, so there’s never a flood of options too early. Players learn as they go, one mechanic at a time, making it one of the best D&D games for beginners.

Tyranny

A Dark Story About Power And Morality Told Through Fast-Paced RPG Gameplay

Tyranny
9 /10
Released
November 10, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
t
Developer(s)
Obsidian Entertainment
Powered by

Tyranny feels close to Baldur’s Gate 3 in how it treats story choices. Every decision shapes the world, alters alliances, and shifts how others see the player and their actions. The setting is dark and political, with factions and betrayals that echo BG3 ’s moral tension.

That said, Tyranny is overall far easier to handle. The campaign is shorter and tighter, with clear goals instead of sprawling side plots. Its mechanics are focused on a smaller range of abilities and party synergies, so players spend less time stuck in menus and more time making decisions that count. Battles are tactical but straightforward with fewer status effects, cleaner skill trees, and faster pacing.

Pillars Of Eternity 2: Deadfire

An Open-World RPG Where Choices Matter But Gameplay Is Relaxed

Pillars of Eternity II: Deadfire
8.8 /10
Released
May 8, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
Mature 17+ // Blood and Gore, Nudity, Sexual Themes, Strong Language, Violence
Developer(s)
Obsidian Entertainment
Powered by

Pillars of Eternity 2: Deadfire ’s world is vast and filled with factions, moral dilemmas, and deep lore. It gives players the freedom to tackle missions in multiple ways—talk, sneak, or fight, much like Baldur's Gate 3 ’s flexible structure—but Deadfire is easier to control and understand. Its combat plays out in real-time with a pause function, allowing players to stop the action, assign tasks, and resume without pressure. This design makes tough battles more forgiving, since mistakes can be corrected mid-fight.

There’s also a strong AI system for companions, so repetitive commands aren’t required. Players can focus more on big decisions and less on micromanaging every turn. The progression system lets players specialize without getting lost in a maze of subclasses or modifiers, keeping the focus on the story and its implications.

Sword Coast Legends

A Beginner-Friendly D&D Adventure With Smooth Party-Based Action

Sword Coast Legends
Action RPG
Isometric
Multiplayer
Systems
Released
October 20, 2015
ESRB
T For Teen // Violence, Blood, Mild Language, Use of Alcohol
Developer(s)
n-Space, Digital Extremes

Powered by

When it comes to the party-based exploration, fantasy classes, and tactical fights, Sword Coast Legends isn’t all that different from Baldur’s Gate 3 . Explore dungeons, command a small team, and fight using spells and abilities drawn from traditional D&D mechanics. It’s a faithful but simpler take on the same world that inspired Baldur's Gate 3 .

Sword Coast Legends ’ campaign is shorter, the areas are smaller, and the systems are stripped down. Players won’t need to memorize complicated dice mechanics or manage too many skill types. Fights rely on timing and the ability to use skills instead of deep environmental or status effect systems. The difficulty curve is gentle, and most encounters are easy to read after a few minutes.

Sword Coast Legends was delisted a long time ago, so you cannot buy it anymore or play on multiplayer servers. For people who own a copy on Steam or something, you should still be able to play offline.

Black Geyser: Couriers Of Darkness

Classic CRPG Feel With Easier Progression

Platforms

PC, macOS, Linux

Released

March 17, 2022

Developer

GrapeOcean Technologies

Genre

CRPG

Black Geyser: Couriers of Darkness plays a lot like the original Baldur’s Gate games, with its isometric view, real-time combat with pause, and classic party control. That structure automatically puts it in line with Baldur’s Gate 3 , which modernized those same roots. It also offers multiple character builds and moral choices that affect every journey.

The combat uses traditional systems that are easy to understand, like clear hit percentages, readable skill trees, and straightforward cooldowns. There are no complex environmental physics or hidden dice rolls behind every move. Players can pause whenever they want, issue orders, and watch the results unfold without feeling rushed or overwhelmed.

Wasteland 3

A Tactical RPG With Easy Turn-Based Combat

Wasteland 3
9 /10
9.6 /10
Released
August 28, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
m
Developer(s)
inXile entertainment
Powered by

Wasteland 3 might look different from Baldur’s Gate 3 , as it’s set in a frozen post-apocalyptic world instead of a medieval fantasy one, but the design philosophy is very similar. It’s all about choice, consequence, and team-based tactics. Like BG3 , decisions made through dialogue shape the story and can even kill or save major characters. The player controls a squad, manages resources, and approaches missions through diplomacy, stealth, or violence.

The big reason Wasteland 3 feels easier is its clarity. Combat works on a grid-based, turn-based system that resembles strategy games like XCOM . While Baldur’s Gate 3 can overwhelm new players with its unrestrained freedom, Wasteland 3 guides them through more focused encounters and concise dialogue trees. The story reacts heavily to any choices made, but the mechanics remain simple and easy to master.

145
9.7 /10
9 /10

Baldur's Gate 3

item.title: Games With The Most Addictive & Satisfying Gameplay Loops
item.description:
The 2018 reboot of God of War is a great game, along with other story-focused games, including The Last of Us Part 2 and Alan Wake 2 . These are all wonderfully exciting games in their own way, but they’re not necessarily addictive. Some of the best games out there have great pacing that makes it feel natural when players want to take a break from the action.

Then there are some games wherein the gameplay is so addictive that players cannot be bothered to put the game down. Hours may go by, and important things like eating can be forgotten. Players shouldn’t be careless about their bodies, but that said, these games are indeed worth zoning out to.

Diablo 4

Loot,Baby, Loot

Diablo 4
9 /10
116
7.5 /10
Released
June 5, 2023

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
Mature 17+ / Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Language, In-Game Purchases, Users Interact
Powered by

The Diablo series is the ultimate loot game that helped establish the genre. While the latest entry, Diablo 4 , pushed the franchise to new heights by introducing an open-world and a compelling story, among other innovations, the core gameplay loop remained intact. Follow the story or side quests, kill enemies, level up, and collect loot. What makes the Diablo gameplay even more satisfying is playing with friends and replaying the game with new classes or difficulty levels.

Monster Hunter Wilds

Chasing Armored Dreams

Monster Hunter Wilds
58
8.2 /10
Released
February 28, 2025

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen // Violence, Blood, Crude Humor
Powered by

The Monster Hunter series was designed to be replayed repeatedly to obtain the best weapons and armor. Monster Hunter Wilds is the latest entry and the one that’s most accessible, thanks to quality of life changes like the open-world and NPC party members that can join hunts.

Players can create their character, choose a weapon that acts as their class, and then follow the story to unlock new monsters to hunt across several diverse biomes. Replaying hunts is an easy way to grind for materials to make badass-looking armor and weapons to get prepared for the next, even more challenging hunt.

Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles

Unlocking That Next Job

Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles
Tactical
RPG
Strategy
Systems
8 /10
8.3 /10
Released
September 30, 2025
ESRB
Teen / Fantasy Violence, Blood, Mild Suggestive Themes, Mild Language, Drug Reference

Powered by

Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles is a remaster of a PS1 game, and it’s the best tactical game to get started with. While the story is one of the game’s better elements, the cutscenes don’t overstay their welcome. Players can get back into the action in minutes, whether they want to grind for EXP, Gil, or other materials.

The game's best feature is the Job system, as it can be addicting to try and unlock all of them and their accompanying skills. Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles is a game that is balanced to perfection, and the Switch 2 is a great platform for it.

SteamWorld Dig 2

Dirt Meets Pickaxe

SteamWorld Dig 2
8.0 /10
Released
September 21, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
e
Powered by

Digging is one of the most satisfying mechanics in a game, as arcade goers learned in the 80s with Dig Dug . Decades later, SteamWorld Dig 2 mesmerized digging fans with a whole new set of gameplay elements.

As Dorothy, a robot girl, players will use their pickaxe in the mines below. Once they run out of steam or inventory space, they will need to return to town, refuel, sell materials, and repeat. There is more of a point, as it’s also a Metroidvania centered on a rescue mission, but the core mechanic of digging is what players will find most compelling.

Dave The Diver

Sushi Can’t Catch Itself

Dave the Diver
9.3 /10
Released
June 28, 2023

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ Due To Fantasy Violence, Use of Alcohol, Mild Blood
Powered by

Dave the Diver defies genres, as it is hard to pinpoint exactly what box it falls into. It has elements of a roguelike, as players will dive into the ocean during the day to catch fish, and the waters will provide different feasts in-between runs without any kind of detrimental penalty. At night, players run their sushi bar with what they caught, sort of like a food-based sim game. Both gameplay segments combine into the perfect formula to get players hooked — pun intended.

Loop Hero

It’s In The Name

Loop Hero
9 /10
7.0 /10
Released
March 4, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Fantasy Violence, Language, Mild Suggestive Themes
Powered by

Loop Hero is based on a time loop wherein the end of the world has happened, but one single warrior is determined to help rebuild society. Each run will place players on a specific loop. Going around it can lead to discoveries like equipment or monsters, which will be slain automatically.

It’s not a passive experience like a clicker game, but it is one of the most chill roguelikes ever made. With simple graphics and an even simpler set of gameplay mechanics, Loop Hero will be an easy game to learn but a hard one to master.

Mercenary Kings: Reloaded Edition

Monster Hunter For Guns

Mercenary Kings
Action
Adventure
Indie
RPG
Systems
Released
July 22, 2013

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
T // Violence, Blood and Gore, Comic Mischief, Use of Tobacco, Mild Suggestive Themes
Powered by

Mercenary Kings: Reloaded Edition is a bit like a mashup between Metal Slug and Monster Hunter . A group of soldiers set up shop on a special island, wherein a mad scientist bred monsters and soldiers, resulting in a big fiasco.

Players are tasked with cleaning up the debacle one quick mission at a time, either alone or with up to three other friends. They will gather materials on a run to make wild guns like a toilet that can shoot exploding bullets. The weapon combinations are both lethal and hilarious, and the animations are beyond gorgeous.

Puzzle Quest: Challenge Of The Warlords

The Challenge Is Putting It Down

Puzzle Quest: Challenge Of The Warlords
Puzzle
RPG
Systems
Released
March 20, 2007

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
e
Powered by

Puzzle Quest: Challenge of the Warlords is a novel little combination of puzzle games and RPGs. Players can choose a class and then go on an epic campaign fighting other adventurers and monsters through turn-based puzzle gameplay. Match the right colors, and players can unleash special abilities or chain bonuses together.

Puzzles should go by quickly, making the need to play again that much more addictive. Thanks to recent remasters, most consoles should have a version or two to check out, like Puzzle Quest: The Legend Returns and Puzzle Quest: Immortal Edition .

item.title: Grow a Garden: Best Crops Tier List
item.description:
With pets having been added to Roblox 's Grow a Garden , your farmland has gotten a whole new glow-up. Yet, there is a variety of plants you can place there to make it even more beautiful. With every update, the roster keeps growing, and players now have tons of crop options to choose from. All of them, however, aren't profitable, since some are just temporary plants that vanish after picking, and others regrow but are quite cheap. Thankfully, there are viable options as well, so here's a full tier list explaining all the available crops and which ones are worth investing your Sheckles in.

Updated by Somiya Adrees on October 25, 2025: Grow a Garden now has 135 crops after the 1.29.0 update, including fruits, veggies, flowers, candy, and bone plants. As such, the tier list featured below has been updated to rank all the new ones and the old favorites (except the Gardener Seed Pack ones), allowing players to uncover which ones truly are the best of the best.

Grow a Garden's Best Crops Tier List

The rankings mostly go by how much money a plant makes from its base price . The list also covers every crop added so far, even the ones you can’t get anymore. Since lots of players still have them growing, this list can help you figure out if they're worth keeping or tossing.

If you're unsure how to use the tier list, here's a quick breakdown:

  • S-tier crops bring in the most profit.
  • A-tier crops are still solid, but don’t earn as much as S-tier.
  • B-tier offers a decent Sheckle average.
  • C-tier doesn’t pay much, but it’s a reasonable option for beginners without better crops.
  • D-tier crops aren’t worth planting at all unless you like how they look or need them for an event.

The “Estimated Profit Per Harvest” column shows the ideal amount of money you can get from each harvest. For crops that aren’t multi-harvest, their full profit is listed directly.

All Crops

Tier Ranking

Reasoning

Estimated Profit Per Harvest

Crimson Thorn

S Tier

A new Transcendent Seed, available in the Seed Shop, grants 7 to 8 Thorns, with one valued at 210k Sheckles.

1,470,000 Sheckles

Candy Blossom

S Tier

Another top pick. Delivers 12 Candy Blossom fruits per round, with every one going for over 100k Sheckles.

1,200,000 Sheckles

Maple Resin

S Tier

The transcendent plant from the Fall event that sells a fruit for 190k, usually giving about 6 to 7.

1,140,000 Sheckles

Bone Blossom

S Tier

The best plant right now , blessing you with 4 to 5 fruits per harvest cycle (priced at 200k). It’s neck-and-neck with Candy Blossom, though that depends on how many fruits your Candy Tree ends up growing.

800,000 Sheckles

Cocomango

S Tier

An OP evergreen crop from Sam’s Seed Shop Tier 2. It drops 4 to 5 cocomangos. Think of it like a coconut tree but with mangoes, each worth 180k.

720,000 Sheckles

Evo Apple

S Tier

Though it starts as a single-harvest plant at Tier I, it’s definitely worth grabbing for its Tier IV version, where it starts regrowing and can bring in around 660k Sheckles in profit; each Evo Apple IV sells for 165k.

660,000 Sheckles

Moon Mango

S Tier

Second best to Bone Blossom and Candy Blossom, it’s a multi-harvest crop that spawns 13 to 20 mangoes at a time, each valued at 50k Sheckles.

650,000 Sheckles

Naval Wort

S Tier

A Season Pass seed that blesses 4 Worts, with one priced at 150k in-game money.

600,000 Sheckles

Multitrap

S Tier

A Divine Seed from the Prime Seed Pack, designed like 3 Venus Flytraps growing from one plant (priced at 180k).

540,000 Sheckles

Dragon Pepper

S Tier

Reharvestable fruit that yields 6 fruits per round, each priced at 88,800 Sheckles.

532,800 Sheckles

Fossilight

S Tier

Keeps up with Dragon Pepper in how many fruits it makes, but can't top its value and total earnings (88k each).

528,000 Sheckles

Moon Blossom

S Tier

Grants 8 to 10 flowers, and each one sells for 66k.

528,000 Sheckles

Inferno Quince

S Tier

Like grape, it has a long stem where 4 Quinces grow each cycle, with one worth 130k in-game currency.

520,000 Sheckles

Acorn

S Tier

A super rare divine seed from the Nutty Chest that yields 4 Acorns (123k each).

492,492 Sheckles

Cyclamen

S Tier

A divine seed found in the Skyroot Chest that grows into 5 flowers.

475,000 Sheckles

Weeping Branch

S Tier

Spawns a huge tree with 3 to 4 long scary branches. Each unit gives 155k. It also has a passive ability that blesses nearby plants with Evo mutations, with the third mutation having a 50x multiplier.

465,000 Sheckles

Elephant Ears

S Tier

Yields 6 fruits per harvest, each selling for 77k.

462,000 Sheckles

Poison Apple

S Tier

A Halloween Market exclusive crop that grows 4 to 5 Poison Apples on the tree, each worth 111k.

444,444 Sheckles

Giant Pinecone

S Tier

Not as profitable as Fossilight and Dragon Pepper, it yields 6 fruits worth 72k each.

432,000 Sheckles

Blood Orange

S Tier

This spooky seed is worth a lot of Candy Corns. It gives 3 harvests, and each sells for 140k.

420,000 Sheckles

Great Pumpkin

S Tier

A multi-harvest crop and the first in GaG to give plants the Ghostly mutation (25x multiplier).

180,000 Sheckles

Sugar Apple

A Tier

Better than Moon Blossom, Hive Fruit, and Beanstalk, but not as valuable as Dragon Pepper and Elephant Ears. Grows 8 apples at once, each selling for 48k Sheckles.

384,000 Sheckles

Tranquil Bloom

A Tier

One of the few plants with a high selling value, 4 blooms at 93k a pop.

372,000 Sheckles

Potato

A Tier

It’s a small plant with flowers on top, but it drops 4 potatoes, each worth about 90k base value.

360,000 Sheckles

Brussels Sprout

A Tier

You’ll get 3 Brussels Sprouts from this crop, each selling for 120k. Not a bad choice from Sam’s Seed Shop Tier 2.

360,000 Sheckles

Firewell

A Tier

The Divine seed from the Fall Seed Pack that produces 2 to 3 Firewells, each valued at 112,111. Its design resembles fallen leaves but can also grow glowing fruits.

336,336 Sheckles

Golden Peach

A Tier

A valuable peach crop that gives 4 glowing peaches, with a base price of 88k for one.

325,000 Sheckles

Poseidon Plant

A Tier

A bright, lovely fruit that grows in 5 and sells for 65k.

325,000 Sheckles

Candy Cornflower

A Tier

From the 1.28.0 update, this is an upgraded version of corn. It’s reharvestable, and the tree grows about 7 to 8 cornflowers (44k each).

311,108 Sheckles

Hive Fruit

A Tier

It provides 5 fruits at once, each worth around 62k Sheckles.

310,000 Sheckles

Beanstalk

A Tier

Beanstalk keeps growing back after each cycle, letting you collect up to 11 at a time, each selling for 28k.

308,000 Sheckles

Pecan

A Tier

A premium seed introduced in the 1.26.0 update. Its single fruit sells for 100k.

300,000 Sheckles

Mangrove

A Tier

A plant with reddish-brown or pale leaves that grows 3 to 4 propagule fruits shaped like long stick-like pods, sold for 100k.

300,000 Sheckles

Traveler's Fruit

A Tier

This crop from the Mega Harvest update yields 5 fruits per harvest, with each fruit selling for 59k.

295,000 Sheckles

Auburn Pine

A Tier

A mythical seed from Fall Event Part 2 that grows into a big tree with 4 auburn pines hanging from it each cycle (one for 73,555 Sheckles).

294,220 Sheckles

Elder Strawberry

A Tier

Not your average berry bush, pulls in 3 to 4 strawberries per round, and they're 90k a pop.

270,000 Sheckles

Spiked Mango

A Tier

Makes 4 to 5 thorny spiked mangoes, each with a good base value of 67,500 Sheckles.

270,000 Sheckles

Grand Tomato

A Tier

Like Elder Strawberry gives around 3 to 4 tomatoes, each going for about 88k.

268,000 Sheckles

Seer Vine

A Tier

A spooky seed that produces eye-shaped fruit, is reharvestable, and sells for 88k each.

266,664 Sheckles

Glass Kiwi

A Tier

A kiwi crop that’s more lucrative than other similar fruit seeds, is re-harvestable, and sells for 65k per unit.

260,000 Sheckles

Lily of the Valley

A Tier

With 5 flowers popping up per harvest, Lily of the Valley can cash in big, with each bloom selling for up to 49k.

245,600 Sheckles

Nectarine

A Tier

Grants 5 fruits at once, with each selling for nearly 48k Sheckles.

240,000 Sheckles

Maple Apple

A Tier

About 3 to 5 Maple Apples pop out per harvest, each selling for 77,777 Sheckles.

233,331 Sheckles

Bitter Melon

A Tier

The best plant from the Connoisseur Event (1.18.0 update), it nourishes into 3 to 4 melons that sell for 77k each.

231,000 Sheckles

Gleamroot

A Tier

A mythical plant that spawns three greenish crops, each worth 75k Sheckles.

225,000 Sheckles

Mummy's Hand

A Tier

As expected for a Halloween seed, it grows into a spooky plant wrapped in cloth strips. Two roots appear at a time, shaped like mummy hands (111k/unit).

222,222 Sheckles

Firefly Fern

A Tier

Offers stronger returns than Burning Bud after its nerf (three ferns per round at 72k base value).

216,000 Sheckles

Serenity

A Tier

Around seven flowers bloom on the plant, and one of them is priced at 30k.

210,000 Sheckles

Guanabana

A Tier

The Guanabana crop spawns a minimum of 3 fruits, with each one selling for 70k.

210,320 Sheckles

Grand Volcania

A Tier

Produces 3 flowers at once, and each one sells for 70k Sheckles.

210,000 Sheckles

Rosy Delight

A Tier

A multi-harvest crop that gives 3 roses, each valued at 69k.

207,000 Sheckles

Parasol Flower

A Tier

Offers good value despite being a single-harvest plant.

200,000 Sheckles (One-time)

Severed Spine

A Tier

The profit you get from each plant can also depend on the size and weight of its fruits . Some crops may be better than others if they consistently grow heavier-than-average fruits. For example, Moon Mango has a lower base profit than Maple Apple but often grows big fruits, meaning it can end up earning more than its listed value.

Best Plants for Stacking Mutations in Grow a Garden

While the tier list above ranks crops by overall value, some GaG plants may have lower total profitability, but higher base value per fruit, making them ideal for stacking mutations. By combining mutations from weather effects, pets, and tools, you can turn their worth into the trillions.

Best Plants for Stacking Mutations

Base Price

Avg Fruit Count

Crimson Thorn

210,000 Sheckles

7 to 8

Bone Blossom

200,000 Sheckles

4 to 5

Maple Resin

190,000 Sheckles

6 to 7

Candy Blossom

100,000 Sheckles

Moon Mango

50,000 Sheckles

13 to 20

Special fruits like Bone Blossoms can also become massive using the Sprinkler method , which further increases their selling price.

Best Seeds in Grow a Garden

Here’s a quick look at the must-have plants in Grow a Garden :

  • The Crimson Thorn seed is part of the current meta in GaG . It produces lots of premium units, making them great for selling directly, and even better when mutated to boost profits further.
  • Candy Blossom and Maple Resin are also among the best seeds in Grow a Garden right now. Candy Blossom has been popular since the early updates, while Maple Resin gained attention after the Fall update. A single harvest from either sells for a huge amount.
  • Bone Blossom and Moon Mango rank among the top 7 plants in the tier list. Bone Blossom can grow 5 fruits, while the Mango tree can produce up to 20 at once. If not, replanting with the Reclaimer is always a solid option.
  • Among Tier 1 seeds in the Seed Shop, Sugar Apple comes right after Crimson Thorn. It’s a strong non-event plant, but Cocomango from Tier 2 outshines it in both price and profit, you just have to grind a bit to unlock it.
  • Finally, in the 1.29.0 update , Blood Orange, Weeping Branch and Severed Spine are definitely worth grinding. Weeping Branch also has a passive, making nearby plants go through three mutation cycles: Wilted (10x), Withered (20x), and Desolate (50x).

item.title: Pokemon’s Leaked Legends: Galar Starters Are Already Clear
item.description:
The release of Pokemon Legends: Z-A marks the second entry in the "Legends" subseries of the franchise, and puts a new spin on the action-RPG gameplay pioneered by Pokemon Legends: Arceus . The popularity of Pokemon Legends: Arceus and now Pokemon Legends: Z-A makes a third entry feel inevitable, and some of the details of this title already seem set in stone. Alongside the likelihood of a Galar Region setting, there are already three obvious choices for the starters of the next Pokemon Legends game.

Predicting the starters for a Pokemon Legends game is more difficult than it seems, after Pokémon Legends: Z-A 's starters broke the established trend with two Gen 2 critters, Chikorita and Totodile. However, in doing so, Pokemon Legends: Z-A makes the starters for the next game a no-brainer to bring the series full circle. With Galar as the most likely stop for the next Pokemon Legends game, the available starters seem primed to follow in Legends: Z-A 's footsteps.

All Signs Point to the Next Pokemon Legends Game Heading to Galar

Pokemon Legends: Z-A makes plenty of references to the Galar Region, which is geographically close to Kalos, given the two regions' UK and France inspirations, respectively. Players can obtain a few different Galarian regional variants in Pokemon Legends: Z-A , and several NPCs mention the culture of Galar in their dialogue. With these hints sprinkled throughout Legends: Z-A , it seems like Galar is set to receive some more attention after first debuting in Gen 8's Pokemon Sword and Shield .

Pokemon Legends: Galar Was Recently Leaked

As part of the recent TeraLeak 2.0 that revealed Pokemon Gen 10, plans for a Pokemon Legends 3 game were detailed as well. This leak confirms the theory that the Galar Region will be the setting for Legends: Z-A's follow-up, taking place over 1,000 years in the past and diving into the origins of the first Gigantamax Poke Ball. The starters for these games may look very different, given that Legends: Arceus introduced new Regional Forms and Legends: Z-A gave its starters Mega Evolutions, but they still have the chance to fill in a gap created by the previous two Legends games.

The Pokemon Legends Series is Missing Three Obvious Starters

  • Snivy
  • Litten
  • Popplio

Of all the unused starters a Pokemon Legends: Galar game could include, Snivy, Litten, and Popplio are the most likely candidates. So far, the Pokemon Legends series has included all three Gen 2 starters, two of three Gen 5 starters, and only one of three Gen 7 starters:

  • Pokemon Legends: Arceus
    • Rowlet (Gen 7)
    • Cyndaquil (Gen 2)
    • Oshawott (Gen 5)

  • Pokemon Legends: Z-A
    • Chikorita (Gen 2)
    • Tepig (Gen 5)
    • Totodile (Gen 2)

To bring the Legends subseries full circle, Snivy would make the most sense as the Grass-type starter, since it is the lone remaining Gen 5 starter to not yet be featured. With Pokemon Legends: Z-A 's starters completing the Gen 2 trio, Litten and Popplio are the obvious choices for a Fire-type starter and a Water-type starter, respectively, since they would join Legends: Arceus ' Rowlet to complete the Gen 7 starter trio.

As Pokemon Legends: Z-A has established, it's possible for two starters of the same generation to appear as starters for a Legends game. So, Litten and Popplio are both on the table for a Pokemon Legends: Galar game.

The leaked details of this Pokemon Legends: Galar game suggest that Gigantamaxing will be the focus of the game's story. As such, these starters will likely get new Gigantamax Forms, much like the Regional Variants and Mega Evolutions the previous games' starters received. None of these starters have received Gigantamax forms in the past, which makes them more likely starter options than mons like Venusaur, Charizard, and Blastoise, who have already been given G-Max Forms.
